metadata.notes: Raw aggregated data - may contain duplicates. Entries with similar names/locations flagged for review.

locations.name: Point Loma Tide Pools
locations.description: One of the best protected rocky intertidal areas in California. Over 350,000 visitors annually.
tips: Accessible approximately two hours before and after low tide
Groups of 10+ need permits for tides of 0.7 feet or lower
Park closes at 4:30 PM

locations.name: Cabrillo National Monument
also_known_as: Point Loma Tide Pools at Cabrillo
locations.description: Protected park area with limited beach access. One of San Diego's premier tide pool destinations.
tips: Designated parking area near tide pools
Kiosk provides guidance
Best times when tide is 0.7 feet or lower

locations.name: Sunset Cliffs Beach
locations.description: Famous sunset-watching spot with water filling flat rock channels at low tide. Hundreds of sea anemones, crabs and fish. Rocky terrain on north side of stairs.
tips: Stairs roughly where Ladera Street and Sunset Cliffs Boulevard meet
Street parking and nearby dirt lot available
Don't scramble down sandstone cliffs - use stairs (erosion hazard)
Area between Adair and Osprey streets closed for safety
Descent to Garbage Beach can be tricky - it's steep

locations.name: Ocean Beach Tide Pools
locations.description: Low-lying sandstone rocks beneath the historic Ocean Beach Pier. One of the best tide pool spots for kids - rocks are relatively flat with shallow pools between them. Eclectic Ocean Beach neighborhood.
tips: Pier at end of Newport Avenue - can't miss it
Small parking lot north of pier (usually full)
Look for metered street parking or paid lots
Ensure kids wear proper footwear for slippery terrain

locations.name: La Jolla Tide Pools
locations.description: Among the most famous and accessible tide pools in Southern California. Multiple spots along the seven-mile La Jolla coastline. Part of the San Diego-La Jolla Underwater Park with strict conservation rules.
locations.best_season: November through March (negative low tides during daylight)
tips: Best times: late October through March when minus tides happen during daylight
Check tide charts - go when tide is at zero or shows a minus
Tours available via Birch Aquarium
Wear sturdy non-slip shoes (no flip-flops)
Take only pictures, leave only footprints
In the Ecological Reserve (La Jolla Cove to La Jolla Shores), may not remove anything including shells
Dogs not allowed on beaches Nov 1 - Mar 31 between 9am-4pm

locations.name: La Jolla Cove & Hospitals Reef
locations.description: Rocky reefs hosting colorful sea stars, anemones, crabs, and occasional sea urchin. Rugged waterfront area along Coast Boulevard.
tips: Multiple parking areas along Coast Boulevard
Seal and sea lion viewing opportunities nearby

locations.name: Hospital Beach
locations.description: Rugged waterfront area along Coast Boulevard.

locations.name: Whispering Sands Beach
locations.description: Located at northern end of Marine Street Beach.

locations.name: Wipeout Beach
locations.description: Sandy beach with rocky areas south of Children's Pool. From here to Hospital Point (passing Whale View Point) is a favorite tide pooling stretch. The curved pools at Hospitals are popular on Instagram.
tips: Street parking on Coast Blvd or Coast Blvd South
Look for Coast Boulevard Park grass strip - Hospital Point is right below
Stay for sunset

locations.name: La Jolla Caves Beach
locations.description: Hidden rocky beach between La Jolla Cove and La Jolla Shores Beach.

locations.name: Dike Rock Tide Pools
locations.description: Located just north of Scripps Pier. Sandy habitat interspersed with big rock formations. This is where Birch Aquarium hosts tide pooling tours - one of the best tide pools in La Jolla with less crowded beach area.
tips: Park in La Jolla Shores Beach parking lot, walk north past Scripps Pier
Alternative: park along El Paseo Grande Street, use cement stairway south of Caroline's Seaside Cafe
UC San Diego parking lots require permits
Sandy habitat draws juvenile fish, blind gobies, and different shrimp
If quiet and watching for a moment, animals will reveal themselves

locations.name: Shell Beach
locations.description: Little hidden gem adjacent to Ellen Browning Scripps Park. Sometimes reveals itself even in summer. Nearby Seal Rock Reserve offshore is protected for sea lions. Great starting point to walk between multiple tide pool areas.
tips: Stairway at southern end of Ellen Browning Scripps Park - look for 'Shell Beach' engraved on cement
Look for green hut (belvedere) above - great spot to watch waves
Cement stairway can be blocked by rocks - tread carefully
Can walk south to Children's Pool, South Casa Beach, and Hospital Point
Can walk north to La Jolla Cove

locations.name: South Casa Beach
locations.description: Behind the Children's Pool sea wall and lifeguard station. Easy for kids to explore thanks to combination of sand and rocks.
tips: Access via stairway behind Children's Pool lifeguard station
Can walk from La Jolla Cove via Shell Beach
People tend to collect shells here - please leave them for hermit crabs

locations.name: La Jolla Shores Beach (South of Marine Room)
locations.description: Reef formation south of The Marine Room restaurant. High numbers of baby sea hares spotted at low tides. Can combine with Dike Rock visit - about 20 minute walk on sand between them.
tips: Park in La Jolla Shores Beach parking lot and walk south
Alternative: park on streets near Marine Room, use public beach access south of La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club

locations.name: False Point
locations.description: Secluded Bird Rock location with abundant pebbles and shallow spots. Rarely crowded. Many rocks are loose - can flip them over to find sea creatures (remember to put back). Former Birch Aquarium tour location.
tips: Access from Sea Ridge Drive and Linda Way intersection
Relatively steep staircase down to beach
Rocks are very slippery - be careful with kids
Stay for sunset - incredible ocean views
Large rocks can be challenging to navigate unless very low tide

locations.name: Tourmaline Surfing Park Tide Pools
locations.description: Popular surfing spot with extensive tide pools tucked away in soft sandstone and on larger boulder field. Located a few minutes walk north of the surfing area.
tips: Park in lot at Tourmaline St. and La Jolla Blvd, walk north to boulder field
Rocks typically covered with slippery algae - good grip shoes essential
Look for snails in sand before reaching rocks - they like to hide
Carry a plastic bag - trash and microtrash washes up here

locations.name: Tide Beach Park
locations.description: Northern Solana Beach with long stairway access.

locations.name: Cardiff State Beach – Seaside Beach
locations.description: 45-million-year-old sedimentary rocks with embedded clam fossils - a rare sight you won't see at other tide pools. Table Top Reef becomes exposed at low tides and is super cool to walk on. About 30 minutes north of La Jolla.
tips: Located at south end of parking lot by the bluffs
Look for information board with tide pool illustrations before walking down
Find pools south of Lifeguard Tower #10
Drive along PCH past Solana Beach, just north of Lomas Santa Fe Drive

locations.name: Swami's Beach
locations.description: Local's favorite beach with substantial reef formation. Famous for excellent surf break. Contains oyster fossils. Can walk to San Elijo Lagoon and South Carlsbad Beach jetty from here.
tips: Tide pools are north of the stairs
Public lot at staircase top, street parking available
Tall staircase from bluffs to beach
Look for wooden tiki head statue on grass - no visible signs
Stay for sunset to watch surfers catch last waves
Continue north along PCH from Cardiff until you see southernmost part of Encinitas

locations.name: Terramar Beach
locations.description: Narrow beach in front of Terramar community. Excellent tidepooling experience.
tips: Small lot near beach entrance
Street parking nearby
Can fill quickly on weekends
Short staircase descent to beach

locations.name: Carlsbad Tide Pools
locations.description: Located between Power Plant and South Carlsbad. Features chameleon moss that literally changes colors.
tips: Best viewing during low tide

locations.name: Coronado Beach Tide Pools
locations.description: Right in front of the Hotel del Coronado. Not large but good for kids - don't have to wander far onto rocks to see marine life. Historic SS Monte Carlo 1920s gambling ship wreckage visible at VERY low tides after El Nino storms.
tips: Tide pools are on hotel side of the jetty
Can pay to park at resort or find street parking
Walk along rocky shoreline in morning for sand dollars and shells

locations.name: Dana Point Tide Pools
locations.description: Marine Protected Area behind the Ocean Institute at Dana Point Harbor. Large boulders and rocks extending for several hundred yards at the foot of huge cliffs. Volunteer docents sometimes present on weekends at low tide.
tips: Take Dana Point Harbor Drive to Ocean Institute parking
Rock scrambling required; strollers impractical
Bring water, sunscreen, windbreakers
High surf advisories may close the area
Dogs prohibited on beach but allowed on leash to benches
Stay back from unstable cliffs
Never remove animals, shells or rocks - observe only
Ocean Institute Visitor Center open Thu-Fri 11am-2pm, Sat-Sun 10am-4pm
Ocean Institute offers naturalist-led 2-hour tide pool hikes

locations.name: Dana Strand Beach
locations.description: Public beach at gated housing development.

locations.name: Salt Creek Beach
locations.description: Wide sandy beach park in Dana Point.

locations.name: Thousand Steps Beach
locations.description: Large sandy beach in south Laguna. Deep, secluded pools. Accessible via challenging 218 step descent.
tips: Watch swell - dangerous wave conditions possible
Also suitable for scuba diving, snorkeling, skimboarding

locations.name: Treasure Island Beach
locations.description: Located right below the Montage Resort. South of Montage Resort.
tips: At low tide, you will see a ton of sea life
Visitors have even seen seals

locations.name: Victoria Beach
locations.description: Long white sand beach south of Victoria Drive.

locations.name: Woods Cove Beach
locations.description: Rocky points at both ends of cove.

locations.name: Table Rock Beach
locations.description: A local hot spot, one of the best tide pools in Orange County where you can explore sea caves and abundant sea life.

locations.name: Aliso Beach
locations.description: Flanked by tide pools on both sides.

locations.name: Rockpile Beach
locations.description: Southern beach of Heisler Park with south-facing exposure.

locations.name: Heisler Park
locations.description: Perched on the bluffs above the ocean, offers breathtaking panoramic views and easy access to some of the best tide pools in Southern California.

locations.name: Shaw's Cove Beach
locations.description: Small sandy cove below homes. A hidden gem within Laguna State Beach Marine Preserve.
tips: Put 999 Cliff Drive into your GPS
Perfect for swimming, snorkeling, and scuba diving

locations.name: Boat Canyon Beach at Fishermans Cove
locations.description: Small south-facing beach tucked away in Laguna Beach.

locations.name: Crescent Bay Beach
locations.description: Picturesque and popular crescent-shaped beach in northern Laguna Beach.

locations.name: Main Beach Tide Pools
locations.description: Flanking the iconic Main Beach, these easily accessible pools offer a glimpse into the intertidal zone.

locations.name: Reef Point Beach
locations.description: Part of Crystal Cove State Park. Large day-use parking at Reef Point Drive. Particularly spectacular with rich marine habitats.
tips: Diversity of sea life is remarkable
Visitors have spotted everything from bright orange sea stars to tiny fish

locations.name: Pelican Point Beach
locations.description: Part of Crystal Cove State Park. Broad beach with day-use parking nearby.

locations.name: Treasure Cove Beach
locations.description: Part of Crystal Cove State Park. Accessed from hiking trails that lead down the steep bluff. Little Treasure Cove is a sea cave only reachable when tide is super low.

locations.name: Crystal Cove State Park
locations.description: Crown jewel of tide pooling destinations. Four tidepools: Reef Point, Rocky Bight, Pelican Point, and Treasure Cove. Pristine park with untouched feel.
tips: Parking $15 per day
Los Trancos lot has trolley access
Located off PCH between Corona del Mar and Laguna Beach

locations.name: Cameo Shores Beach
locations.description: Sandy beach below Cameo Shores community.

locations.name: Little Corona Del Mar Beach
locations.description: Popular small beach at the end of Buck Gully ravine. Offers easily accessible tide pools that are perfect for families.
tips: Rocky areas are relatively safe to navigate
Best for younger explorers - easy access without steep stairs

locations.name: Point Fermin Park Beach
locations.description: Beach below steep bluffs with lighthouse nearby. Rocky beach (not sandy) with tide pools and beachcombing.
tips: Two access routes from Paseo Del Mar (via Leland Street or Meyler/Roxbury Streets)

locations.name: White Point Beach
locations.description: Below steep bluffs, much safer to access than nearby Palos Verdes coves. More than 1.5 miles of rocky coastline with unique tide pools.
tips: 30 acres of parkland
Ample parking
Swimming not recommended

locations.name: Sacred Cove Beach
locations.description: Part of Abalone Cove Shoreline Park. Deep cove.

locations.name: Abalone Cove Beach
locations.description: One of the best places in all of SoCal for tidepooling.
locations.status: PERMANENTLY CLOSED - landslides and dangerous conditions

locations.name: Golden Cove
locations.description: Semicircular cove with some of the best tide pools on the PV Peninsula.
tips: Steep access not suitable for small children
Wear traction shoes, avoid strollers

locations.name: Malaga Cove Beach
locations.description: Rocky shoreline with tide pools accessible via the Malaga Cove Trail.
tips: Park near Paseo Del Mar and Via Arroyo intersection
Trail begins on north side of lot
Choose left fork at bluff base for rocky shore and pools
Right fork leads to sandy beach

locations.name: Christmas Tree Cove
locations.description: Rocky cove with steep access.

locations.name: Honeymoon Cove
locations.description: Small cove surrounded by high bluffs. Very steep access.

locations.name: Malibu Lagoon State Beach
locations.description: One of the best tidepools near Los Angeles for first-time visitors. Sandy beach access plus rocky pools at low tide.

locations.name: El Matador State Beach
locations.description: The best tide pools in Los Angeles. Features secluded caves and rock arches. Local photoshoot favorite.
tips: Location: PCH south of Encinal Canyon Road
Steep path and stairs
Caves accessible only at low tide
Recommended for older children due to challenging terrain

locations.name: Leo Carrillo State Park – South Beach
locations.description: 1.5-mile beach stretch with tide pools at Sequit Point and coastal caverns. Excellent exploring opportunities.
tips: Pay parking
Tunnel under PCH to reach sand

locations.name: Point Dume State Beach
locations.description: Excellent tide pools at this headland location. Features headlands, cliffs, rocky coves, and a large beach.
tips: Whale watching December through mid-April

potential_duplicates.reason: Same coordinates, same location - likely the same place with different names
Same coordinates, Hospital Beach is part of the larger area
Both in Carlsbad, may refer to same general area
Rockpile Beach is within Heisler Park
